Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing (ACM/IEEE SEC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to assist United States-based graduate students to attend the Third Association for Computer Machinery (ACM)/Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) Symposium on Edge Computing (SEC 2018) in Bellevue, Washington. Participation in SEC 2018 and similar conferences are valuable and important activities of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers, and exposes students to leading work and practical industry practices in this important area of research. This may have an important impact on career development.

The conference will be held in Bellevue, Washington on October 25-27, will span three days, and will consist of technical paper presentations, panels, posters, and demonstrations. It will also feature keynote speeches from leading researchers and practitioners in the field.

Student travel to conferences is an important activity. Funds will be dispersed with preference given to students who would not otherwise be able to attend the conference and students who are not already scheduled to present a paper, paying particular attention to diversity and relevance of the student's research interest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Binghamton
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to support travels of US-based students to attend the ACM/IEEE Symposium on Edge Computing (SEC), which took place in Bellevue, Washington from Oct. 25-27, 2018.

We received 26 applications for the travel grant from students in the US institutions. In the end we awarded 20 students to receive the grant, with each student to receive up to $1,000 for the award. We was also able to support another 5 applicants by the conference sponsorship. 

Among the 20 grant recipients,

- all were enrolled in a CISE (Computer and Information Science and Engineering) related Ph.D. program at the time when the conference took place;

- 7 students (35% of all the recipients) are from under-represented groups (6 female students and 1 Hispanic male student);

- 11 students (55%) first attended the SEC conference due to this travel grant support;

- 10 students (50%) first received a travel grant from NSF;

- 8 students (40%) students had a first-authored paper to present at the conference; and

- 9 students (45%) participated the Ph.D. forum of the conference.

All the supported students attended the conference and the poster/demo session.

 

The following students were awarded this grant:

- ﻿Qi Xia (The College of William and Mary)

- Xiao Zhu (University of Michigan)

- Tayebeh Bahreini (Wayne State University)

- Sumit Maheshwari (Rutgers University)

- Daniel Zhang (University of Notre Dame)

- Junjue Wang (Carnegie Mellon University)

- Ziqiang Feng (Carnegie Mellon University)

- Shweta Khare (Vanderbilt University)

- Rahmadi Trimananda   (University of California, Irvine)

- Liangkai Liu (Wayne State University)

- Tarek Elgamal (University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign)

- Rufaida Ahmed (University of Utah)

- Mengyuan Chao (Texas A&M University)

- Lanyu Xu (Wayne State University)

- Matthew Turner (University of Kentucky)

- Ke-Jou Hsu (Georgia Tech)

- Servio Palacios (Purdue University)

- Harshit Daga (Georgia Institute of Technology)

- Hossein Badri (Wayne State University)

- Shilpa George (Carnegie Mellon University)

A photo of part of the student awardees at the conference is attached.

Modified by: Yifan Zhang
